add_error_handler ( *callback*, *block = True*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1762-L1796) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_error_handler) Registers an error handler in the Application. This handler will receive every error
which happens in your bot. See the docs of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error"> `process_error()`</a> for more details on how
errors are handled.

Note

Attempts to add the same callback multiple times will be ignored.

Examples

[Errorhandler Bot](examples.errorhandlerbot.html)

See also

[Exceptions, Warnings and Logging](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/wiki/Exceptions%252C-Warnings-and-Logging)

Parameters:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_error_handler.params.callback">**callback**</a>   ([coroutine function](https://docs.python.org/3/glossary.html#term-coroutine-function)   ) â€“

  The callback function for this error handler.
Will be called when an error is raised. Callback signature:

  async   def   callback   (   update  :   Optional   [object   ],   context  :   CallbackContext   )   The error that happened will be present in<a href="telegram.ext.callbackcontext.html#telegram.ext.CallbackContext.error"> `telegram.ext.CallbackContext.error`</a>  .

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_error_handler.params.block">**block**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool"> `bool`</a>   , optional) â€“ Determines whether the return value of the callback
should be awaited before processing the next error handler in<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error"> `process_error()`</a>   . Defaults to<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True"> `True`</a>  .

add_handler ( *handler*, *group = 0*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1318-L1382) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handler) Register a handler.

TL;DR: Order and priority counts. 0 or 1 handlers per group will be used. End handling of
update with<a href="telegram.ext.applicationhandlerstop.html#telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop"> `telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop`</a>.

A handler must be an instance of a subclass of<a href="telegram.ext.basehandler.html#telegram.ext.BaseHandler"> `telegram.ext.BaseHandler`</a> . All
handlers
are organized in groups with a numeric value. The default group is 0. All groups will be
evaluated for handling an update, but only 0 or 1 handler per group will be used. If<a href="telegram.ext.applicationhandlerstop.html#telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop"> `telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop`</a> is raised from one of the handlers, no further
handlers (regardless of the group) will be called.

The priority/order of handlers is determined as follows:

- Priority of the group (lower group number == higher priority)
- The first handler in a group which can handle an update (see<a href="telegram.ext.basehandler.html#telegram.ext.BaseHandler.check_update"> `telegram.ext.BaseHandler.check_update`</a>   ) will be used. Other handlers from the
group will not be used. The order in which handlers were added to the group defines the
priority.

Warning

Adding persistent<a href="telegram.ext.conversationhandler.html#telegram.ext.ConversationHandler"> `telegram.ext.ConversationHandler`</a> after the application has
been initialized is discouraged. This is because the persisted conversation states need
to be loaded into memory while the application is already processing updates, which
might lead to race conditions and undesired behavior. In particular, current
conversation states may be overridden by the loaded data.

Parameters:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handler.params.handler">**handler**</a>   (<a href="telegram.ext.basehandler.html#telegram.ext.BaseHandler"> `telegram.ext.BaseHandler`</a>   ) â€“ A BaseHandler instance.
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handler.params.group">**group**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   , optional) â€“ The group identifier. Default is `0`  .

add_handlers ( *handlers*, *group = 0*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1383-L1441) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handlers) Registers multiple handlers at once. The order of the handlers in the passed
sequence(s) matters. See<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handler"> `add_handler()`</a> for details.

Added in version 20.0.

Parameters:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handlers.params.handlers">**handlers**</a>   (Sequence[<a href="telegram.ext.basehandler.html#telegram.ext.BaseHandler"> `telegram.ext.BaseHandler`</a>   ] |                 dict[int, Sequence[<a href="telegram.ext.basehandler.html#telegram.ext.BaseHandler"> `telegram.ext.BaseHandler`</a>   ]]) â€“

  Specify a sequence of handlers*or*a dictionary where the keys are groups and
values are handlers.

  Changed in version 21.7:   Accepts any<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.abc.html#collections.abc.Sequence"> `collections.abc.Sequence`</a>   as input instead of just a list
or tuple.

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handlers.params.group">**group**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   , optional) â€“ Specify which group the sequence of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_handlers.params.handlers"> `handlers`</a>   should be added to. Defaults to `0`  .

Example:

app. add_handlers ( handlers = { - 1: [MessageHandler ( ... )], 1: [CallbackQueryHandler ( ... ), CommandHandler ( ... )] } Raises: <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#TypeError">**TypeError**</a> â€“ If the combination of arguments is invalid.

create_task ( *coroutine*, *update = None*, ***, *name = None*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1074-L1113) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.create_task) Thin wrapper around<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-task.html#asyncio.create_task"> `asyncio.create_task()`</a> that handles exceptions raised by

Note

- If<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.create_task.params.coroutine"> `coroutine`</a>   raises an exception, it will be set on the task created by
this method even though itâ€™s handled by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error"> `process_error()`</a>  .

- If the application is currently running, tasks created by this method will be
awaited with<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop"> `stop()`</a>  .

See also

[Concurrency](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/wiki/Concurrency)

Parameters:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.create_task.params.coroutine">**coroutine**</a>   ([awaitable](https://docs.python.org/3/glossary.html#term-awaitable)   ) â€“

  The awaitable to run as task.

  Changed in version 20.2:   Accepts<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-future.html#asyncio.Future"> `asyncio.Future`</a>   and generator-based coroutine functions.

  Deprecated since version 20.4:   Since Python 3.12, generator-based coroutine functions are no longer accepted.

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.create_task.params.update">**update**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#object"> `object`</a>   , optional) â€“ If set, will be passed to<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error"> `process_error()`</a>   as additional information for the error handlers. Moreover, the corresponding<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.chat_data"> `chat_data`</a>   and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.user_data"> `user_data`</a>   entries will be updated in the next run of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_persistence"> `update_persistence()`</a>   after the<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.create_task.params.coroutine"> `coroutine`</a>   is finished.

Keyword Arguments: <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.create_task.params.name">**name**</a> (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a> , optional) â€“

The name of the task.

Added in version 20.4.

Returns: The created task.

Return type:<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-task.html#asyncio.Task"> `asyncio.Task`</a>

mark_data_for_update_persistence ( *chat_ids = None*, *user_ids = None*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1578-L1607) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.mark_data_for_update_persistence) Mark entries of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.chat_data"> `chat_data`</a> and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.user_data"> `user_data`</a> to be updated on the next
run of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_persistence"> `update_persistence()`</a>.

Tip

Use this method sparingly. If you have to use this method, it likely means that you
access and modify `context.application.chat/user_data[some_id]` within a callback.
Note that for data which should be available globally in all handler callbacks
independent of the chat/user, it is recommended to use<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.bot_data"> `bot_data`</a> instead.

Added in version 20.3.

Parameters:

migrate_chat_data ( *message = None*, *old_chat_id = None*, *new_chat_id = None*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1496-L1562) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data) Moves the contents of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.chat_data"> `chat_data`</a> at key<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.old_chat_id"> `old_chat_id`</a> to the key<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.new_chat_id"> `new_chat_id`</a> . Also marks the entries to be updated accordingly in the next run
of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_persistence"> `update_persistence()`</a>.

Warning

- Any data stored in<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.chat_data"> `chat_data`</a>   at key<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.new_chat_id"> `new_chat_id`</a>   will be
overridden

- The key<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.old_chat_id"> `old_chat_id`</a>   of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.chat_data"> `chat_data`</a>   will be deleted
- This does not update the<a href="telegram.ext.job.html#telegram.ext.Job.chat_id"> `chat_id`</a>   attribute of any scheduled<a href="telegram.ext.job.html#telegram.ext.Job"> `telegram.ext.Job`</a>  .

When using<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.concurrent_updates"> `concurrent_updates`</a> or the<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.job_queue"> `job_queue`</a>,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_update"> `process_update()`</a> or<a href="telegram.ext.job.html#telegram.ext.Job.run"> `telegram.ext.Job.run()`</a> may re-create the old entry due
to the asynchronous nature of these features. Please make sure that your program can
avoid or handle such situations.

See also

[Storing Bot, User and Chat Related Data](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/wiki/Storing-bot%252C-user-and-chat-related-data)

Parameters:

  A message with either<a href="telegram.message.html#telegram.Message.migrate_from_chat_id"> `migrate_from_chat_id`</a>   or<a href="telegram.message.html#telegram.Message.migrate_to_chat_id"> `migrate_to_chat_id`</a>   .
Mutually exclusive with passing<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.old_chat_id"> `old_chat_id`</a>   and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.new_chat_id"> `new_chat_id`</a>  .

  See also

<a href="telegram.ext.filters.html#telegram.ext.filters.StatusUpdate.MIGRATE"> `telegram.ext.filters.StatusUpdate.MIGRATE`</a>

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.old_chat_id">**old_chat_id**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   , optional) â€“ The old chat ID.
Mutually exclusive with passing<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.message"> `message`</a>

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.new_chat_id">**new_chat_id**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   , optional) â€“ The new chat ID.
Mutually exclusive with passing<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.migrate_chat_data.params.message"> `message`</a>

*async*process_error ( *update*, *error*, *job = None*, *coroutine = None*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1806-L1891) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error) Processes an error by passing it to all error handlers registered with<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_error_handler"> `add_error_handler()`</a> . If one of the error handlers raises<a href="telegram.ext.applicationhandlerstop.html#telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop"> `telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop`</a> , the error will not be handled by other error
handlers. Raising<a href="telegram.ext.applicationhandlerstop.html#telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop"> `telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop`</a> also stops processing of
the update when this method is called by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_update"> `process_update()`</a> , i.e. no further handlers
(even in other groups) will handle the update. All other exceptions raised by an error
handler will just be logged.

Changed in version 20.0:

- `dispatch_error`   was renamed to<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error"> `process_error()`</a>  .
- Exceptions raised by error handlers are now properly logged.
- <a href="telegram.ext.applicationhandlerstop.html#telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop"> `telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop`</a>   is no longer reraised but converted into
the return value.

Parameters:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error.params.update">**update**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#object"> `object`</a>   |<a href="telegram.update.html#telegram.Update"> `telegram.Update`</a>   ) â€“ The update that caused the error.
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error.params.error">**error**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#Exception"> `Exception`</a>   ) â€“ The error that was raised.
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error.params.job">**job**</a>   (<a href="telegram.ext.job.html#telegram.ext.Job"> `telegram.ext.Job`</a>   , optional) â€“

  The job that caused the error.

  Added in version 20.0.

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_error.params.coroutine">**coroutine**</a>   ([coroutine function](https://docs.python.org/3/glossary.html#term-coroutine-function)   , optional) â€“ The coroutine that caused the error.

Returns:<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True"> `True`</a> , if one of the error handlers raised<a href="telegram.ext.applicationhandlerstop.html#telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop"> `telegram.ext.ApplicationHandlerStop`</a>.<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False"> `False`</a> , otherwise.

Return type:<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool"> `bool`</a>

*async*process_update ( *update*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1236-L1317) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_update) Processes a single update and marks the update to be updated by the persistence later.

run_polling ( *poll_interval = 0.0*, *timeout = 10*, *bootstrap_retries = 0*, *allowed_updates = None*, *drop_pending_updates = None*, *close_loop = True*, *stop_signals = None*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L739-L845) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling) Convenience method that takes care of initializing and starting the app,
polling updates from Telegram using<a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling"> `telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling()`</a> and
a graceful shutdown of the app on exit.

The app will shut down when<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#KeyboardInterrupt"> `KeyboardInterrupt`</a> or<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#SystemExit"> `SystemExit`</a> is raised. This also works from within handlers, error handlers and jobs. However, using<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop_running"> `stop_running()`</a> will give a somewhat cleaner shutdown behavior than manually raising those exceptions. On unix, the app will also shut down on receiving the signals specified by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.stop_signals"> `stop_signals`</a>.

The order of execution by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling()`</a> is roughly as follows:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.initialize"> `initialize()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_init"> `post_init()`</a>
- <a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling"> `telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.start"> `start()`</a>
- Run the application until the users stops it
- <a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.stop"> `telegram.ext.Updater.stop()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop"> `stop()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_stop"> `post_stop()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.shutdown"> `shutdown()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_shutdown"> `post_shutdown()`</a>

A small wrapper is passed to<a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling.params.error_callback"> `telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling.error_callback`</a> which forwards errors occurring during polling to<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.add_error_handler"> `registered error handlers`</a> . The update parameter of the callback
will be set to<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None"> `None`</a>.

Tip

- When combining `python-telegram-bot`   with other<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio.html#module-asyncio"> `asyncio`</a>   based frameworks, using this
method is likely not the best choice, as it blocks the event loop until it receives a stop
signal as described above.
Instead, you can manually call the methods listed below to start and shut down the application
and the<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.updater"> `updater`</a>   .
Keeping the event loop running and listening for a stop signal is then up to you.

- To gracefully stop the execution of this method from within a handler, job or error callback,
use<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop_running"> `stop_running()`</a>  .

Changed in version Removed: the deprecated parameters `read_timeout`, `write_timeout`, `connect_timeout` , and `pool_timeout` . Use the corresponding methods in<a href="telegram.ext.applicationbuilder.html#telegram.ext.ApplicationBuilder"> `telegram.ext.ApplicationBuilder`</a> instead.

Parameters:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.poll_interval">**poll_interval**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#float"> `float`</a>   , optional) â€“ Time to wait between polling updates from
Telegram in seconds. Default is `0.0`  .

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.timeout">**timeout**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   , optional) â€“ Passed to<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.get_updates.params.timeout"> `telegram.Bot.get_updates.timeout`</a>   . Default is `10`   seconds.
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.bootstrap_retries">**bootstrap_retries**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   , optional) â€“

  Whether the bootstrapping phase
(calling<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.initialize"> `initialize()`</a>   and the boostrapping of<a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling"> `telegram.ext.Updater.start_polling()`</a>   )
will retry on failures on the Telegram server.

  - < 0 - retry indefinitely
  - 0 - no retries (default)
  - > 0 - retry up to X times

  Changed in version 21.11:   The default value will be changed to from `-1`   to `0`   . Indefinite retries
during bootstrapping are not recommended.

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.drop_pending_updates">**drop_pending_updates**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool"> `bool`</a>   , optional) â€“ Whether to clean any pending updates on
Telegram servers before actually starting to poll. Default is<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False"> `False`</a>  .

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.allowed_updates">**allowed_updates**</a>   (Sequence[<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a>   ], optional) â€“

  Passed to<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.get_updates"> `telegram.Bot.get_updates()`</a>  .

  Changed in version 21.9:   Accepts any<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.abc.html#collections.abc.Sequence"> `collections.abc.Sequence`</a>   as input instead of just a list

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.close_loop">**close_loop**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool"> `bool`</a>   , optional) â€“

  If<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True"> `True`</a>   , the current event loop will be
closed upon shutdown. Defaults to<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True"> `True`</a>  .

  See also

<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.loop.close"> `asyncio.loop.close()`</a>

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling.params.stop_signals">**stop_signals**</a>   (Sequence[<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   ] |<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None"> `None`</a>   , optional) â€“

  Signals that will shut
down the app. Pass<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None"> `None`</a>   to not use stop signals.
Defaults to<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/signal.html#signal.SIGINT"> `signal.SIGINT`</a>  ,<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/signal.html#signal.SIGTERM"> `signal.SIGTERM`</a>   and<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/signal.html#signal.SIGABRT"> `signal.SIGABRT`</a>   on non Windows platforms.

  Caution

  Not every<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.AbstractEventLoop"> `asyncio.AbstractEventLoop`</a>   implements<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.loop.add_signal_handler"> `asyncio.loop.add_signal_handler()`</a>   . Most notably, the standard event loop
on Windows,<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.ProactorEventLoop"> `asyncio.ProactorEventLoop`</a>   , does not implement this method.
If this method is not available, stop signals can not be set.

Raises: <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#RuntimeError">**RuntimeError**</a> â€“ If the Application does not have an<a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater"> `telegram.ext.Updater`</a>.

run_webhook ( *listen = '127.0.0.1'*, *port = 80*, *url_path = ''*, *cert = None*, *key = None*, *bootstrap_retries = 0*, *webhook_url = None*, *allowed_updates = None*, *drop_pending_updates = None*, *ip_address = None*, *max_connections = 40*, *close_loop = True*, *stop_signals = None*, *secret_token = None*, *unix = None*) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L846-L1005) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook) Convenience method that takes care of initializing and starting the app,
listening for updates from Telegram using<a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.start_webhook"> `telegram.ext.Updater.start_webhook()`</a> and
a graceful shutdown of the app on exit.

The app will shut down when<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#KeyboardInterrupt"> `KeyboardInterrupt`</a> or<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#SystemExit"> `SystemExit`</a> is raised. This also works from within handlers, error handlers and jobs. However, using<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop_running"> `stop_running()`</a> will give a somewhat cleaner shutdown behavior than manually raising those exceptions. On unix, the app will also shut down on receiving the signals specified by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.stop_signals"> `stop_signals`</a>.

If<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.cert"> `cert`</a> and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.key"> `key`</a> are not provided, the webhook will be started directly on `http://listen:port/url_path` , so SSL can be handled by another
application. Else, the webhook will be started on `https://listen:port/url_path` . Also calls<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.set_webhook"> `telegram.Bot.set_webhook()`</a> as
required.

The order of execution by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook()`</a> is roughly as follows:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.initialize"> `initialize()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_init"> `post_init()`</a>
- <a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.start_webhook"> `telegram.ext.Updater.start_webhook()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.start"> `start()`</a>
- Run the application until the users stops it
- <a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.stop"> `telegram.ext.Updater.stop()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop"> `stop()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_stop"> `post_stop()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.shutdown"> `shutdown()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_shutdown"> `post_shutdown()`</a>

Important

pip install "python-telegram-bot[webhooks]" Tip

- When combining `python-telegram-bot`   with other<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio.html#module-asyncio"> `asyncio`</a>   based frameworks, using this
method is likely not the best choice, as it blocks the event loop until it receives a stop
signal as described above.
Instead, you can manually call the methods listed below to start and shut down the application
and the<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.updater"> `updater`</a>   .
Keeping the event loop running and listening for a stop signal is then up to you.

- To gracefully stop the execution of this method from within a handler, job or error callback,
use<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop_running"> `stop_running()`</a>  .

See also

[Webhooks](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/wiki/Webhooks)

  - 0 - no retries (default)
  - > 0 - retry up to X times
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.webhook_url">**webhook_url**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a>   , optional) â€“ Explicitly specify the webhook url. Useful behind
NAT, reverse proxy, etc. Default is derived from<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.listen"> `listen`</a>  ,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.port"> `port`</a>  ,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.url_path"> `url_path`</a>  ,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.cert"> `cert`</a>   , and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.key"> `key`</a>  .

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.allowed_updates">**allowed_updates**</a>   (Sequence[<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a>   ], optional) â€“

  Passed to<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.set_webhook"> `telegram.Bot.set_webhook()`</a>  .

  Changed in version 21.9:   Accepts any<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.abc.html#collections.abc.Sequence"> `collections.abc.Sequence`</a>   as input instead of just a list

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.drop_pending_updates">**drop_pending_updates**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool"> `bool`</a>   , optional) â€“ Whether to clean any pending updates on
Telegram servers before actually starting to poll. Default is<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#False"> `False`</a>  .

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.ip_address">**ip_address**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a>   , optional) â€“ Passed to<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.set_webhook"> `telegram.Bot.set_webhook()`</a>  .
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.max_connections">**max_connections**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   , optional) â€“ Passed to<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.set_webhook"> `telegram.Bot.set_webhook()`</a>   . Defaults to `40`  .
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.close_loop">**close_loop**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bool"> `bool`</a>   , optional) â€“

  If<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True"> `True`</a>   , the current event loop will be
closed upon shutdown. Defaults to<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#True"> `True`</a>  .

  See also

<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.loop.close"> `asyncio.loop.close()`</a>

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.stop_signals">**stop_signals**</a>   (Sequence[<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#int"> `int`</a>   ] |<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None"> `None`</a>   , optional) â€“

  Signals that will shut
down the app. Pass<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/constants.html#None"> `None`</a>   to not use stop signals.
Defaults to<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/signal.html#signal.SIGINT"> `signal.SIGINT`</a>  ,<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/signal.html#signal.SIGTERM"> `signal.SIGTERM`</a>   and<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/signal.html#signal.SIGABRT"> `signal.SIGABRT`</a>  .

  Caution

  Not every<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.AbstractEventLoop"> `asyncio.AbstractEventLoop`</a>   implements<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.loop.add_signal_handler"> `asyncio.loop.add_signal_handler()`</a>   . Most notably, the standard event loop
on Windows,<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html#asyncio.ProactorEventLoop"> `asyncio.ProactorEventLoop`</a>   , does not implement this method.
If this method is not available, stop signals can not be set.

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.secret_token">**secret_token**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a>   , optional) â€“

  Secret token to ensure webhook requests originate
from Telegram. See<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.set_webhook.params.secret_token"> `telegram.Bot.set_webhook.secret_token`</a>   for more
details.

  When added, the web server started by this call will expect the token to be set in
the `X-Telegram-Bot-Api-Secret-Token`   header of an incoming request and will
raise a<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/http.html#http.HTTPStatus"> `http.HTTPStatus.FORBIDDEN`</a>   error if either the
header isnâ€™t set or it is set to a wrong token.

  Added in version 20.0.

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.unix">**unix**</a>   (<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.Path"> `pathlib.Path`</a>   |<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a>   |<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/socket.html#socket.socket"> `socket.socket`</a>   , optional) â€“

  Can be
either:

  - the path to the unix socket file as<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.Path"> `pathlib.Path`</a>     or<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str"> `str`</a>     . This
will be passed to[tornado.netutil.bind_unix_socket](https://www.tornadoweb.org/en/stable/netutil.html#tornado.netutil.bind_unix_socket)     to create the socket.
If the Path does not exist, the file will be created.

  - or the socket itself. This option allows you to e.g. restrict the permissions of
the socket for improved security. Note that you need to pass the correct family,
type and socket options yourself.

  Caution

  This parameter is a replacement for the default TCP bind. Therefore, it is
mutually exclusive with<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.listen"> `listen`</a>   and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.port"> `port`</a>   . When using
this param, you must also run a reverse proxy to the unix socket and set the
appropriate<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook.params.webhook_url"> `webhook_url`</a>  .

  Added in version 20.8.

  Changed in version 21.1:   Added support to pass a socket instance itself.

*property*running [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L397-L405) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.running) Indicates if this application is running.

<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.start"> `start()`</a>,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop"> `stop()`</a>

*async*shutdown ( ) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L515-L553) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.shutdown) Shuts down the Application by shutting down:

- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.bot"> `bot`</a>   by calling<a href="telegram.bot.html#telegram.Bot.shutdown"> `telegram.Bot.shutdown()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.updater"> `updater`</a>   by calling<a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.shutdown"> `telegram.ext.Updater.shutdown()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.persistence"> `persistence`</a>   by calling<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_persistence"> `update_persistence()`</a>   and<a href="telegram.ext.basepersistence.html#telegram.ext.BasePersistence.flush"> `BasePersistence.flush()`</a>
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_processor"> `update_processor`</a>   by calling<a href="telegram.ext.baseupdateprocessor.html#telegram.ext.BaseUpdateProcessor.shutdown"> `telegram.ext.BaseUpdateProcessor.shutdown()`</a>

Does *not*call<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_shutdown"> `post_shutdown`</a> - that is only done by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling()`</a> and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook()`</a>.

See also

<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.initialize"> `initialize()`</a>

Raises: <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#RuntimeError">**RuntimeError**</a> â€“ If the application is still<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.running"> `running`</a>.

*async*start ( ) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L583-L635) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.start) Starts

- a background task that fetches updates from<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_queue"> `update_queue`</a>   and processes them via<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.process_update"> `process_update()`</a>  .
- <a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.job_queue"> `job_queue`</a>   , if set.
- a background task that calls<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_persistence"> `update_persistence()`</a>   in regular intervals, if<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.persistence"> `persistence`</a>   is set.

Note

This does *not*start fetching updates from Telegram. To fetch updates, you need to
either start<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.updater"> `updater`</a> manually or use one of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling()`</a> or<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook()`</a>.

Tip

When using a custom logic for startup and shutdown of the application, eventual
cancellation of pending tasks should happen only after<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop"> `stop()`</a> has been called
in order to ensure that the tasks mentioned above are not cancelled prematurely.

See also

<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop"> `stop()`</a>

Raises: <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#RuntimeError">**RuntimeError**</a> â€“ If the application is already running or was not initialized.

*async*stop ( ) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L636-L701) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop) Stops the process after processing any pending updates or tasks created by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.create_task"> `create_task()`</a> . Also stops<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.job_queue"> `job_queue`</a> , if set.
Finally, calls<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_persistence"> `update_persistence()`</a> and<a href="telegram.ext.basepersistence.html#telegram.ext.BasePersistence.flush"> `BasePersistence.flush()`</a> on<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.persistence"> `persistence`</a> , if set.

Warning

Once this method is called, no more updates will be fetched from<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_queue"> `update_queue`</a> ,
even if itâ€™s not empty.

See also

<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.start"> `start()`</a>

Note

- This does*not*stop<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.updater"> `updater`</a>   . You need to either manually call<a href="telegram.ext.updater.html#telegram.ext.Updater.stop"> `telegram.ext.Updater.stop()`</a>   or use one of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling()`</a>   or<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook()`</a>  .
- Does*not*call<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_stop"> `post_stop`</a>   - that is only done by<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling()`</a>   and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook()`</a>  .

Raises: <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#RuntimeError">**RuntimeError**</a> â€“ If the application is not running.

stop_running ( ) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L702-L738) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.stop_running) This method can be used to stop the execution of<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling()`</a> or<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook()`</a> from within a handler, job or error callback. This allows a graceful
shutdown of the application, i.e. the methods listed in<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling`</a> and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook`</a> will still be executed.

This method can also be called within<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_init"> `post_init()`</a> . This allows for a graceful,
early shutdown of the application if some condition is met (e.g., a database connection
could not be established).

Note

If the application is not running and this method is not called within<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_init"> `post_init()`</a> , this method does nothing.

Warning

This method is designed to for use in combination with<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_polling"> `run_polling()`</a> or<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.run_webhook"> `run_webhook()`</a> . Using this method in combination with a custom logic for starting
and stopping the application is not guaranteed to work as expected. Use at your own
risk.

Added in version 20.5.

Changed in version 21.2: Added support for calling within<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.post_init"> `post_init()`</a>.

*async*update_persistence ( ) [[source]](https://github.com/python-telegram-bot/python-telegram-bot/blob/v22.0/telegram/ext/_application.py#L1630-L1652) [Â¶](about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.update_persistence) Updates<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.user_data"> `user_data`</a>,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.chat_data"> `chat_data`</a>,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.bot_data"> `bot_data`</a> in<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.persistence"> `persistence`</a> along with<a href="telegram.ext.extbot.html#telegram.ext.ExtBot.callback_data_cache"> `callback_data_cache`</a> and the conversation states of
any persistent<a href="telegram.ext.conversationhandler.html#telegram.ext.ConversationHandler"> `ConversationHandler`</a> registered for this application.

For<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.user_data"> `user_data`</a> and<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.chat_data"> `chat_data`</a> , only those entries are updated which either
were used or have been manually marked via<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.mark_data_for_update_persistence"> `mark_data_for_update_persistence()`</a> since
the last run of this method.

Tip

This method will be called in regular intervals by the application. There is usually
no need to call it manually.

Note

Any data is deep copied with<a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html#copy.deepcopy"> `copy.deepcopy()`</a> before handing it over to the
persistence in order to avoid race conditions, so all persisted data must be copyable.

See also

<a href="telegram.ext.basepersistence.html#telegram.ext.BasePersistence.update_interval"> `telegram.ext.BasePersistence.update_interval`</a>,<a href="about:blank#telegram.ext.Application.mark_data_for_update_persistence"> `mark_data_for_update_persistence()`</a>
